Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Interactive effects of predation and ecosystem size on arthropod food webs in Hawaiian forests fragmented by lava flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the combined effects of top predators and ecosystem size on the coexistence of species in food webs. Using numerous forest fragments of varying size that have been naturally created by lava flows in Hawai'i, the researchers will test the hypothesis that, as top predators, non-native rats alter food webs consisting of native birds, insects and spiders, with greater effects in smaller forest fragments. The study will involve experimental removal of rats, experimental exclusion of birds, stable isotope analysis of arthropods, and remote sensing analysis of forest size, complexity and productivity, all across a 100-fold gradient of forest fragment size.

Many forests around the world have been fragmented by development and pastoral land use, and also invaded by rats and other non-native predators. This project will improve the scientific basis for making management decisions, especially with regard to how non-native species removal can be used to restore native forests and how the effect may depend on forest size. This project will also enable the researchers to train a number of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows through their participation in research. Students will be recruited through internship programs at Stanford University and the University of Hawai'i, Hilo, which has a successful record of training under-represented students in environmental sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hawaii's terrestrial ecosystems have been enormously distrupted and altered as a result of human land use, invasive species and disease.  On the Big Island, some native forest remains at mid-elevations where a largely intact community of birds and native plants can be found.  Still, non-native rats have invaded these forests and have many potential effects on these imperiled forest ecosystems.  Using a natural system of forest fragments called kipukas that resulted from natural lava flows about 150 years ago, we designed an experiment to remove rats from half of a set of forest fragments to test for the effects of rats on birds, insects and plants.  Beginning in 2010, rats were removed from about 18 kipuka and were left in the other 18 kipuka ranging in size from 0.1 ha. to 55 ha. Trapping continued to maintain zero to low density of rats for 4 years.  We visually counted birds as well as captured them in mist nets for banding, body measurements and release.  Arthropods and other insects  on clipped and bagged canopy branches were counted and identified to species.  We also conducted timed observations of birds foraging within the forest.  

We found that rats tend to prefer foraging closer to the ground and were largley absent from the forest canopy above 12 m.  Interestingly, foraging observation data showed that where rats were removed, birds tended to forage lower in the canopy suggesting that in the absence of rats, arthropod populations increased, attracting insectivorous birds.  Individual color banding of bird legs provided insight into how different species move within the kipuka landcape with the frugivorous Omao moving far less than the nectivorous I'iwi and Apapane.  We also discovered the first ever confirmed hybridization between two species of endemic honeycreeper, an I'iwi female and Apapane male.
